results.title: Paddle to the sea
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A children’s odyssey, from the story by Holling C. Holling. A film about a little Indian in a canoe, hand-carved in the northern forest and, in the spring, launched towards the sea. There are many adventures, all photographed with great patience and an eye for the beauty of living things. The film gives vivid impressions of Canada’s varied landscape and the life of its waterways. Commentary by Stanley Jackson. Awards: ten awards including Philadelphia; Oscar nomination, Hollywood.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Mason, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Oz shorts. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Anna Johnson, Anne Pratten, Michael Bates, Stuart McDonald, Alison Wotherspoon, Roslyn Walker, AFTRS, Angara, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Hellhole, Motion Art, Much Ado and Puppet Company
results.brief_description: The second part of an innovative and dazzling selection of Australian short films from the 1990s. The films are: “Mr. Electric” (Dir: Stuart McDonald) - in 1953 an Aboriginal man (Ernie Dingo) returns to the country home of his adopted white family to give them the gift of electricity; “Rhino” (Anna Johnson) - a kinetic black and white film combining animation and live action; “Terra Nullius” (Anne Pratten) - a confronting and disturbing film about a young Aboriginal woman dealing with her history as a survivor of incest by her adopted father; “A Passion Play” (Tony Twigg) - a haunting animated film that utilises symbols and paintings to reflect on the nature of communication; “Secrets of the City” (Cathy Linsley) - an animated dream; “Etcetera in Paper Jam” (Michael Bates) - a hilarious short about a photo- copier that turns on humans. Anyone who has worked in an office environment will enjoy this witty attack on “office culture”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Anna Johnson, Anne Pratten, Michael Bates, Stuart McDonald, Alison Wotherspoon, Roslyn Walker, AFTRS, Angara, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria, Hellhole, Motion Art, Much Ado and Puppet Company

results.title: Degenocide: the second best of the original DGeneration
results.creator_credit: David Cameron, Joe Murray, Kris Noble, Peter Ots, Ted Emery, Andrew Knight, Mark Gibson, Michael Hirsch and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This video contains comedy sketches from the 1986 and 1987 ABC seasons of the D-Generation, the best of the 1988 Channel 7 specials inculding ‘Degenocide’, and the re-voicing of ‘Homicide’. Starring such comedy luminaries as Rob Sitch, Magda Szubanski, Santo Cilauro, Marg Downey and Michael Veitch and including such classics as: ‘Thunderbirds’, ‘The Kerrigan Brothers’, ‘The Irish Rovers’ and ‘Tommy Cravat Jnr’, ‘The Dubbo Olympics’ and a very poor snooker trick indeed!

results.title: Degas in the Metropolitan
results.creator_credit: Charles Eames, Jehane Burns, Ray Eames and Metropolitan Museum of Art
results.brief_description: This brilliant comprehensive study of French artist Edgar Degas takes us on a leisurely tour through the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art’s extraordinary collection of his works. An extended presentation of paintings, drawings, prints and sculptures gives a clearly structured view of Degas’ life and career. The music of Satie and Chopin are performed by Zita Carno under the direction of Elmer Bernstein, narrated by Charles S. Moffat.

results.title: Pace
results.creator_credit: John Shaw, Yoram Gross, Brian Woods, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Over 300 years old, the modern sport of trotting was established when the English stallion, Messenger, was imported into the U.S.A. in 1788. About the turn of the century, quality stock arrived in Australia and New Zealand. With skilful breeding, these trotters and pacers rank among the world’s best. In this transformation into a trotter from birth, to breaking school, to racetrack debut, is followed. Filmed at Carlton Stud, Picton, N.S.W., and various Sydney trotting tracks. No narration.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Shaw, Yoram Gross, Brian Woods, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: P.G-H: a modern odyssey
results.creator_credit: I. James Wilson, John Tristram, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Juniper Films
results.brief_description: The life and times of the Australian born composer, Peggy Glanville-Hicks, also known as PG-H, who lived and worked in America with world renowned writers, musicians and choreographers. She became a distinguished music critic for the Hreald Tribune. Her compositions include concertos, sonatas and works for the theatre.
results.creator_credit_for_label: I. James Wilson, John Tristram, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Juniper Films

results.title: Oz: A Rock 'n' Roll Road Movie
results.creator_credit: Chris Lofven, Lyne Helms and Count Features
results.brief_description: An Australian rock movie fable. Dorothy’s teenage quest in the Australia of the 70’s is a modern parable set to Ross Wilson’s music. With three weird friends who alternate between being pals and making passes, Dorothy sets out to find the answer to fame and fortune’s riddle at the hands of the wonderful wizard.

results.title: Oyster man
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy, Julian Biggs, Michael Spencer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of oyster farming in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, showing the various stages of oyster cultivation: the sampling of minute larvae by Department of Fisheries biologists, the staking of oyster beds by farmers, the nurturing of spat, and underwater scenes showing the dragging of the sea bed with cotton mops to ensnare starfish which prey upon the oyster. Final sequences show the grading and shipping of oysters and their arrival at the sea food restaurant or family dinner table, where they delight the eyes and palates of oyster lovers.
